text:
hello this is chef john from food wishes
calm with New England clam chowder Deb

that's right if you can turn a sandwich
into a dip we should certainly be able

to turn a soup into a dip I mean give or
take some extra liquid we're pretty much

already there but anyway after joking
about making this dip in the last video

I thought I would actually give it a try
and it really did turn out amazingly

well the only problem is I thought I was
inventing this which turned out not to

be the case but while this is not
original I think we've made a couple

improvements so let's go ahead and get
started with the first example of that

and that would be the amount of bacon so
into this cold dry pan I'm going to add

six slices of bacon that I've cut up
into like half-inch pieces and what

we'll do is cook this over medium heat
until almost all that fat renders out

and the bacon starts getting nice and
crispy and by using six strips of bacon

here we're doubling or tripling the
amount of bacon that I saw in the other

recipes for New England clam chowder dip
and while there is a danger that we use

so much bacon we sort of overpower that
clam flavor that was a risk I was more

than prepared to take and I ended up
being very happy with my decision but

anyway like I said we're gonna cook that
bacon over medium heat until it's pretty

much fully cooked and one visual clue I
look for is when you start to see a

little bit of foaminess on the bacon
it's usually close to being done okay we

all remember that childhood rhyme when
your bacon starts to foam you're almost

home and what we'll do when it reaches
this point is go ahead and add our

celery and onions but first I do want to
remove a couple tablespoons of bacon to

use for the top so that's what I'm doing
here and we'll just set that aside for

later and then once that's been
accomplished like I said we can go ahead

and add our celery and onions and I'm
using green onions but regular onions

will work and I also tossed in a nice
big pinch of salt and what we'll do is

just leave our heat on medium and cook
those stirring for a couple minutes

until they just start to soften up which
is probably only gonna take about two

minutes
and by the way if you need to drain or

blot some of your bacon grease out of
the pan feel free that is just you

cooking but my bacon was relatively lean
so I didn't need to and then what we'll

do after those veggies have cooked for a
couple minutes is simply turn off the

heat and let those cool down a little
bit while we go ahead and unwrap a

couple pack
or cream cheese and add them to this

mixing bowl and since those packages are
8 ounces each we have 1 pound total I

know Thank You mr. math and then to that
we can go ahead and add our bacon veggie

mixture along with the rest of our clam
chowder dip ingredients which will

obviously need to include some clams and
I'm gonna use a couple six and a half

ounce cans that have been drained and
these are what they call in the business

chopped clams but they also sell mince
clams which would work just as well and

maybe even better and no I'm not sure
why we need minced and chopped clams at

the market but anyway continuing on
we'll also go ahead and toss in some

freshly chopped Italian parsley as well
as a cover so a freshly grated extra

sharp cheddar cheese and I'm suggesting
the white kind not the orange kind since

that would look a little weird and then
we'll go ahead and season this up with a

little bit of Worcestershire sauce now
that and then we will finish up with

some freshly ground black pepper as well
as about a half a teaspoon of old bay

and if you're not sure what that is I'll
tell you on the blog post and then once

all that's in there we'll go ahead and
take a spoon and mix this up which is

super easy because my cream cheese was
nice and soft in room temp and of course

I'm just kidding I forgot to take it out
of the fridge again oh and speaking of

the cheese since people got mad in the
last video I didn't mention where the

cream cheese came from I will confirm
that yes this did come from a certain

city in Pennsylvania no not Pittsburgh
Philadelphia but anyway we'll go ahead

and mix this up until we're confident it
is nicely combined at which point we can

transfer this into the casserole or
baking dish of our choice anything

shallow will work and the exact size and
shape really don't matter as long as

it's oven proof that is kind of
important so we'll go ahead and transfer

that in and smooth out the top and then
you remember those couple tablespoons of

crispy bacon we set aside whatever we
have an Eden of that we'll go ahead and

sprinkle over the top oh yeah you know
recipes pretty easy when the hardest

thing about it is not eating the garnish
which I have to admit is pretty hard but

I was relatively disciplined and most of
it did survive so we'll go ahead and

scatter that over the top and then on
top of that I like to do a little extra

grated cheddar all right not too too
much just a little bit here

a little bit there and then because this
tip is supposed to honor the New England

Patriots we are gonna do a little
cheating before this goes in the oven

what we'll do before we pop this in is
sprinkle some paprika or cayenne over

the top which will help give the surface
even a more beautiful richer color once

this is browned so this is technically
optional and up to you

I mean you are after all the Tom Brady
of being shady and even though I like to

do it I won't be deflated if you don't
either way once that said this is ready

to transfer into the center of a 400
degree oven for about 20 minutes or so

plus maybe a couple minutes under the
broiler or until everything's heated

through and the top is nicely browned
and if everything goes according to plan

it should look something like this
which as far as I'm concerned looks like

something most people would want to eat
and then as far as service goes I'm

gonna go ahead and place this next to
some chips and maybe finish it off a

little bit of freshly chopped Italian
parsley and by the way the chip choice

here is very critical since I wouldn't
consider this a clam chowder dip unless

there was some kind of potato involved
which is why I'm serving mine with these

puffed potato chips and by puffed I mean
pumped and while this would be delicious

on sliced bread which is how every other
clam chowder dip I saw served it I'm

thinking that some kind of potato chip
is gonna work out much better and not

only for the reason I just gave you the
potatoes are an important part of clam

chowder but also I think texturally the
crispness of these works out better than

the soft bread of course having said
that it's pretty hard to eat a dip ROM

so use what you want and by the ways you
may have noticed I used to spoon for the

first one but then I want to make sure
this qualified technically as a dip

which means you have to be able to dip
something into it which I did very

successfully here over and over and over
and above and beyond the amazing clam

chowder like taste
I thought the thickness of this dip was

pretty much spot-on I mean wicked
perfect but I was thinking if you wanted

something just a little bit thinner just
a little looser maybe adding a couple

tablespoons of that clam juice from the
can would not be a bad idea

so just a little something to consider
but anyway that's it what we're calling

New England clam chowder dip sure I love
football and watching TV and hanging

with friends but let's be honest the
best thing about a Super Bowl party

besides watching Cromer
on purpose is being able to be

ridiculous and insanely delicious dips
like this so I really do hope you give

this a try soon head over to food wishes
calm for all the ingredient amounts of
more info as usual and as always enjoy
you
